results.title: The Tracker [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, Julie Ryan, South Australian Film Corporation and Vertigo Productions
results.brief_description: Set in the Australian outback in 1922 and filmed on location in the Flinders Ranges, South Australia, “The Tracker” tells the story of three white men and an indigenous tracker in pursuit of a fugitive. The Tracker (David Gulpilil) is a native policeman during a time in which trackers were employed to find suspects. He answers to The Fanatic (Gary Sweet), a cruel bigot who is hell bent on catching The Fugitive, an aboriginal man accused of murdering a white woman. The Follower (Damon Gameau), is a naive young colonial policeman new to the job while The Veteran (Grant Page) is a world weary man whose kind nature is overridden by what he must do and how society expects him to treat blacks. The three white men are ultimately dependent on the silent, ever watchful tracker. When an interrogation of some bush blacks turns into a massacre, the balance of power shifts and assumed notions of truth and justice are thrown into question. While the film tackles the brutal treatment of Aborigines by white police, De Heer averts a realist portrayal of graphic violence by cutting to paintings (by South Australian artist, Peter Coad) that represent the scenes of brutality and bloodshed. With its sparse use of dialogue, but much of the film’s thematic content - about the displacement of Aboriginal peoples by white settlers, and conflict between white and indigenous systems of justice - is conveyed through songs written by Graham Tardif and performed for the film by indigenous musician, Archie Roach. David Gulpilil won an AFI Award for best actor for his role in the film. Written by Rolf de Heer ; cinematography by Ian Jones ; editing by Tania Nehme. Jointly commissioned by Adelaide Festival of the Arts 2002 and SBS Independent. Also available on VHS [317684].

results.title: Walkabout (1970) [DVD]
results.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister (Jenny Agutter) and her young brother (Lucien John) left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They are rescued by a young aborigine (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood. During their journey Gulpilil courts the young woman, though in her incomprehension she rejects his advances. The vision of paradise lost presented with an often surreal intensity is that of a European outsider, who sees white history as invasive and deeply destructive. Also stars John Meillon, Robert McDara, Pete Carver, John Illingsworth, Hilary Bamberger, Barry Donnelly, Noelene Brown and Carlo Machini. Cinematography by Nicolas Roeg. Screenplay by Edward Bond, based on the novel by James Vance Marshall. Edited by Antony Gibbs and Alan Pattillo. Music composed and conducted by John Barry. Also available on VHS [309075].

results.title: Jedda [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel and Charles Chauvel Productions
results.brief_description: Jedda, Charles Chauvel’s last feature film and Australia’s first in colour, is the story of a teenage Aboriginal girl who has been raised by a white woman, and finds herself drawn to Marbuck, a full-blooded Aborigine who comes to the station for work. The film falls readily into two halves. The first details Jedda’s upbringing and her emotional turmoil as to her identity, which is solved by Jedda herself, when the call of her blood leads her into the physical and psychological world of her people. The second half of the film, photographed in spectacular Central Australian locations, concentrates on the tension of the chase in which Marbuck and Jedda are pursued by the men from Jedda’s station. Cast includes Ngarla Kunoth as Jedda, Robert Tudawali as Marbuck, Betty Suttor, Paul Reynall, George Simpson-Lytle, Tas Fitzer, Wason Byers, Willie Farrar, Margaret Dingle. Also available on VHS [303086].

results.title: Homemade history
results.creator_credit: Robert Herbert, Sophie Jackson, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Film Commission and Arcadia Pictures
results.brief_description: A delightful slice of Australian life, this compilation of home made short films shot on 8mm film are sure to bring back memories or inspire new filmmakers. Memories of everyday life, beach holidays, careers, travel, weddings, music and fashion. Thirteen home movie filmmakers narrate a five minute edited version of their films dating from the 1930s to the 1980s, each ending with a contemporary portrait of the people involved. Aboriginal families, immigrant families, gay and lesbian protest movement and our first Paralympics team are some of the more fascinating works. Seeing a home movie shot in the 1930s and narrated by the filmmaker (the late Les Petty) is simply captivating.

results.title: Wild Australasia
results.creator_credit: Neil Nightingale, Animal Planet, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC
results.brief_description: Wonderful aerial photography of the Australian landscape entices the viewer to voyage with the filmmakers across the continent. A six part television series on wildlife co-produced by the BBC/ABC and narrated by Matt Day. Landscapes, flora and fauna of Australia and parts of New Zealand are explored. Deserts, coral reefs, islands, forests and cities and the unique nature of wildlife in Australasia are portrayed in great, colourful detail. Extras include two bonus documentaries on penguins and possums.

results.title: The Kimberley: land of the Wandjina [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Hogarth, ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Narrated by Leo McKern, this documentary, produced by the award-winning ABC TV Natural History Unit, explores the land and life of the spectacular Kimberley region of North West Australia. Aboriginal people believe that the Wandjina, the rain spirits, created the landscape. From the vast coastal mudflats to the tidal rivers and inland waterways, this beautifully photographed film explores in detail one of the least known regions of Australia.

results.title: Walking through a minefield
results.creator_credit: Cathy Henkel, Jeff Canin, SBS Independent, Australian Film Commission and Hatchling Productions
results.brief_description: A thought provoking documentary on the contentious issue of uranium mining, and in particular the construction of the new Jabiluka uranium mine by mining company Energy Resources of Australia (ERA) in the Kakadu National Park. The film follows the daily conflicts which face the dedicated protesters who have arrived, on invitation by the Aboriginal traditional owners, from all over Australia to set up a blockade to prevent ERA beginning construction at Jabiluka. Through interviews and personal commentary, the filmmakers present the many and varied viewpoints held by all those involved from all sides of the fence including ERA workers and management, protesters, Aboriginal traditional owners, police officers, tourist operators, and residents of the nearby town of Jabiru. Uranium mining has social, economical and political consequences for Australia and the Australian population particularly in light of the government’s intention to allow other mining companies to further develop our uranium industry. A very interesting and insightful program. Narrated by Rachel Griffiths.

results.title: A Track winding back
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
This documentary is based on a true story written by school teacher Carolyn Landon about bushman, Daryl Tonkin and his life and memories of Jackson’s Track in West Gippsland, Victoria. It is a story of love and tragedy, of an Aboriginal community living and working harmoniously with white people in the timber industry in the forest area of Jackson’s Track established by Daryl and his brother Harry during the 1930s. It tells of Daryl’s feud with his family when he decided to live with an Aboriginal woman, the dramatic kidnapping of this woman by his brother, Daryl’s life with the Aboriginal community and the eventual bull-dozing of the camp in the 1960s to appease local Christian groups resulting in the break-up and dispersal of the almost 100 people living at the camp. Daryl talks of himself as being at one with the Aboriginal way of life, a true bushman, who saw his life neither primitive nor of poverty and hardship, but as being his preferred way of life. Includes interviews with two of his nine children, re-enactments, stills and archival footage, and excerpts from the film “Rose against the odds”. Contains some b&w images.

results.title: The Cape crusade
results.creator_credit: Helen Grasswill and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Noel Pearson, Aboriginal lawyer and Cape York adviser, and his brother Gerhardt Pearson, Cape York leader, together and along with several key business people, philanthropists and the corporate world are attempting to change the social disintegration within the Cape York Aboriginal communities. This program explores the establishment of the Indigenous Enterprise Partnerships, a concept and strategy initiated by Noel Pearson, comprising of four private business entities - Westpac, Myer Foundation, Boston Consultancy and Bodyshop - and other leaders in the business world, along with Aboriginal leaders to provide employment and education to the remote indigenous communities and instigate social change especially amongst the younger generation. Disillusioned with Government bureaucracy and the welfare system, Noel and Gerhardt are committed to change, believing that to overcome the unemployment, alcoholism, gambling, illicit drug use, family violence and child abuse, change has to come from within the Aboriginal community itself. “Australian story” presents some of the early successes resulting from the partnership and includes interviews with Ann Sherry (Westpac), Colin Carter (Boston Consultancy), Noel Pearson and Gerhardt Pearson. Hosted by Caroline Jones.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Noel Pearson, Aboriginal lawyer and Cape York adviser, and his brother Gerhardt Pearson, Cape York leader, together and along with several key business people, philanthropists and the corporate world are attempting to change the social disintegration within the Cape York Aboriginal communities. This program explores the establishment of the Indigenous Enterprise Partnerships, a concept and strategy initiated by Noel Pearson, comprising of four private business entities - Westpac, Myer Foundation, Boston Consultancy and Bodyshop - and other leaders in the business world, along with Aboriginal leaders to provide employment and education to the remote indigenous communities and instigate social change especially amongst the younger generation. Disillusioned with Government bureaucracy and the welfare system, Noel and Gerhardt are committed to change, believing that to overcome the unemployment, alcoholism, gambling, illicit drug use, family violence and child abuse, change has to come from within the Aboriginal community itself. “Australian story” presents some of the early successes resulting from the partnership and includes interviews with Ann Sherry (Westpac), Colin Carter (Boston Consultancy), Noel Pearson and Gerhardt Pearson. Hosted by Caroline Jones.

results.title: The Nature of paradise
results.creator_credit: Lucinda Gamble, John Moore, Sally Ingleton, Daryl Dellora, Steve Thomas and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Three women - Trish Molloy (artist), Monique La Fontaine (artist), Sharon Wiggan (law student) - tell their stories, each from a personal perspective, of their relationship and connection to the Western Australian north-west coastal town of Broome. Trish and Monique are travellers who have separately found their way to Broome and stayed and Sharon is an Aboriginal Australian who was brought up in Broome, left to study in Perth and who has now returned home to Broome. The documentary explores each woman’s emotional and spiritual attachment to the town, to their surrounding environment and their kinship with the people of Broome and with each other. Evocative and beautifully photographed by Veronica Iacono, and sensitively scripted and directed by Lucinda Gamble, “The Nature of paradise” is stunningly rich in images and colour, of reds and blues, of the earth, sky and the ocean and is accompanied by an ambient musical soundtrack, “Free diving” written and performed by Lorrei Coffin. Interspersed throughout the documentary are images of both Trish and Monique’s paintings which reflect their transitional journey to this place called “paradise”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lucinda Gamble, John Moore, Sally Ingleton, Daryl Dellora, Steve Thomas and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
